profileText: (Uncle of Christopher Ellery), a Delegate from Rhode Island; born in Newport, R.I., on December 22, 1727; taught by private teachers; was graduated from Harvard College in 1747; naval officer of Rhode Island in 1754; clerk of the court of common pleas of Newport County in 1768 and 1769; studied law; was admitted to the bar in 1770 and commenced practice in Newport, R.I.; elected a Member of the Continental Congress to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Samuel Ward and served from May 14, 1776, to 1785; one of the signers of the Declaration of Independence; chosen to the newly constituted board of admiralty in 1779; appointed chief justice of Rhode Island in 1785; appointed by the Continental Congress commissioner of the Continental Loan Office in 1786; collector of the port of Newport from 1790 until his death in Newport, R.I., February 15, 1820; interment in the Common Cemetery.

researchRecord.name: 1782, 1 page.
researchRecord.description: A letter from William Ellery to General Miller written on September 1, 1782. William Ellery writes: "I have been informed that the Honble. Daniel C. researchRecord.name: 1803, 3 pages.

While the letter is addressed to William Stedman, the letter begins "Dear Almy" and was intended for William Steman's wife, who was William Ellery's daughter. William Ellery gives his daughter advice concerning her health, outlook, exercise, child-rearing, and discusses his fatherhood at some length.

researchRecord.name: 1753-1829, 0.5 linear foot.
researchRecord.description: There are roughly five or six hundred documents of William Ellery in the library's holdings, spread out over at least sixteen different collections. Most of these pertain to William Ellery's career as Customs Collector, and can be found in the Rhode Island Manuscripts and the Providence Customs House collections. The Ellery Collection includes 46 letters from William Ellery and 31 addressed to him. This represents only a portion of his surviving correspondence; photocopies of letters found in other collections at the Rhode Island Historical Society Library have also been placed in this collection. William Ellery had apparently asked that his letters be destroyed after death, but he was a prolific correspondent, and his surviving work exists in a largely miscellaneous state scattered across the nation's archives. Additional documents were recently added to the collection, and contain a large body of William Ellery's notes and memorandum. It includes account books; transcriptions William Ellery made from various sources on religion, history and medicine; probate records for estates William Ellery had an interest in; and scattered correspondence collected by William Ellery for various reasons. While little of this material was actually composed by William Ellery, much of it is in his own hand, and almost all includes a few notes by him as to its significance. Possibly the most important is a memorandum book from 1796 and 1797, which contains some brief diary entries, including a meditation on George Washington on February 22.

researchRecord.name: 1804, 2 items.
researchRecord.description: A letter from William Ellery to James Madison written on January 19, 1804. William Ellery protests his potential removal as Collector for the district of Newport and notes his faithful performance of the job. William Ellery also writes that his family still depends on him for support. He also writes that he is too old to begin another career and hopes that when Thomas Jefferson learns of his feelings, that he will not remove him from office. William Ellery concludes with a plea to James Madison, as an old acquaintance, to lay his situation before the President and to convey his response to him.
